 Support the Troops, With Safer Armor (2 Letters)
 Published: July 3, 2005
 To the Editor:
 
 Re "Safer Vehicles for Soldiers: A Tale of Delays and Glitches" (front page, June 26): 
 
 Why can't we find the money to produce armored vehicles that will insure that soldiers, most of whom come from working-class families, receive the same safe transportation that the politicians receive?
 
 There may be arguments for mobility during incursions or stealth during reconnaissance of which I am not aware, but the Rhino Runner would be my vehicle of choice for those who serve our country.
 
 It's difficult to conceive why Congress or the armed services cannot develop a rapid procurement program to safeguard young soldiers whose leaders have put them in harm's way. 
 
 Lonnie McCullough -- Yardley, Pa., June 26, 2005
 
 To the Editor:
 
 Unarmored Humvees and a lack of medical supplies indicate a consistent record of negligence by the commander in chief, the Defense Department and senior military officers, resulting in needless casualties.
 
 The early logistical failures of the Korean War were used to plan the support required for a major commitment in Vietnam, including the activation of a general hospital in Japan. When the first combat divisions landed in Vietnam, evacuation and field hospitals, fully staffed and equipped, landed with them. 
 
 There was a resolve to provide the best possible support for the troops. Medical supplies, food, water, fuel and safe transportation were supplied by the military, not by profit-motivated, politically connected private contractors.
 
 If we truly support our troops in Iraq, it's time for some answers: Why were we unprepared? Where has the money gone that was supposed to support our troops? Why hasn't Congress corrected the tax law inequities so that all Americans share the cost? 
 
 And most important, why have some in the media been reluctant to report the facts? Ultimately, the media reported on Vietnam, and the truth made us a better nation.
 
 Franklin M. Schall -- Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. -- June 27, 2005
 The writer was an Army supply officer, 1964-66.
